monogr.title: Compendium belli: or the touchstone of martiall discipline : VVherein is set foorth briefe rules and directions to take speciall notice of. The next of marches, exercising of a company, ordering of muskaters, imbattelling from 100. vnto 40000. The forme of encamping, with briefe notes belonging therevnto: plots of fortifications and forts: with the manner of lading and blowing off great ordnance, making of granados. Also shewing the extraction of the square roote, witha table from 16. vnto 10000. Likewise certaine questions of arithmaticke concerning military discipline: with a table also for the discouering of numbers by rancke and file. Witten [sic] by Iohn Roberts of Weston neere Bath, gent
monogr.author: Roberts, John, of Weston

div.head: A Postscript to the Reader.
div.p:
COurteous Reader, I had thought to imposed silence to my Penne, and to haue infused a Period to this my Compendium; But I did thinke fitte to adde these few Lines, as a supplement & Postscript, to show the cause of this my writing. The Causa mouens, or, Primum mobile of it, is a declaratory Instruction to my Countrey-men in generall, but especially to Noble, (though vnexperienced Tyrones) in whom, there is either an inbred, or an aduenticious desire of Millitary Discipline, or to exositate, or stir vp those that are vnexperienced, to a further prosecution of these generous & well beseeming Qualities. The Terminus ad quem, or, the intentiall scope and drift of this, is for the beneficiall good of my Natiue Countrey. From the
first of these, I doe desire their courteous welwishings; from the second, their gratefull acceptation; from the third, their louing approbation: As for the last, though I owe more then I am able, yet when I am able, I will showe more; In the meane time, take this as a depositum.
